content:
You realize that you have not even properly defined what tetration is, right?
We have to figure out from an example for 3: "The notation a^^3 means a^(a^a)."

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice

‚ùå Rejected the contribution.
Comment: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/defining-test-cases

Test cases and validators do not meet the "Each validator must differ from the corresponding test" requirement

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and fun

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice and quick to understand task
im not gonna approve it if gorbit says that the validators are not OK as it is. Please reply to this comment to get my attention when you've satisfied gorbit's request. Really fun puzzle tho

The puzzle is good as an idea, but Gorbit has a valid point, it is not resistant to hard coding and can be highly unfair if someone gets a 100% score in less time.

I read the comments.

SonicFox, can you please try changing just one input and the output from validator? 

Validators are not shown as a Test case.

Solution with 63 characters in Python:
a=int(input())
r=1
for _ in range(int(input())):r=a**r
print(r)
Definitely like the idea, but agree with Gorbit.

‚ùå Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Tests and validators are still the same after 3 days. I'll remove this if that changes.

Tests and validators, shouldn't be the same, they just need to be similar. You should be able to look at each group, and say "oh right, this group tests X" while not having the same answer for both. An example would be "This group tests if you can handle the letter A in a string" or "This group tests if you have error checking". And also, it *should* but doesn't need to be in increasing difficulty, so smallest testcases first, bigger and harder ones last. In your case for example, I would order them by size mainly.

As mentioned previously: tests and validators should be named accordingly.

I would strongly suggest adding a line in both the description and the constraints that the result is below 2^30 so it's fair for all languages and you don't have to worry about overflow. As for me I would be most pleased if the largest number returned would happen in a test case not a validator for fairness. Especially since the algorithm should be fairly simple.

Also worth mentioning that the two last example does not satisfy 1 <= A <= 5 constraint.

Tests must be equivalent to validators. 
Test 3 and validator 4 are not: In some languages (like C++), the result of the validator is too big to be stored in a standard integer, and this is a problem. As a player, seeing only the tests and that I must remove the trailing zeros if the result is an integer, I will probably check if my result have decimals by comparing the result with himself converted to integer. That will pass the test, but not the validator, cause the result is too big for the integer type.
So you have to reduce the validator result or to use another big number in the test.
Don't use floating point numbers where you have to print out 20 digits, limit it to 3 or 4, right now if I try to do this problem, I get floating point errors and can't actually solve it

I'm having the same problem (in Python):
Found:      "80.21178022896636"
Expected: "80.21178022896638"
It seems like this is only an issue of confusion between tests and validators, they should be named accordingly
I applied all the necessary changes. Tell me if I should improve something else.

Sorry but someone says that tests and validators must be equivalent and someone says that they should be different. I really don't know what to do üòÖ. And I'm still confused about the difference between tests and validators that you told me.
Test cases and validators are the same right now
Is it good now?
They should be equivalent in the sense that they need to test similar situations, but they can't be carbon copies of one another. Read the guidelines and look at other submissions
Sorry, it's my first contribution and I haven't clearly understood the difference between tests and validators. Could you help me?
tests are visible to the user, validators are run when you submit, they come in pairs, and a pair should be similar to one another, but different enough to not allow hardcoding
I've just updated my statement and I've removed floating point numbers. Tell me if it works for you.
Yes, that solves the problem :)
